Ibn Rajab said at the end of his book: «Know that what Umar judged is of two divisions: First: What no judgment from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, is known about at all. This is of two types: First: What Umar gathered the Companions for and consulted them about, so they agreed with him on it. This, there is no doubt that it is the truth, like this issue, and the two 'Umariyyah [inheritance cases], and like his judgment regarding the one who had intercourse during his Ihram that he continues his rites, and owes making up [the Hajj] and a sacrificial animal, and many issues. Second: What he did not gather the Companions for, but they differed regarding it in his time. This allows for difference of opinion, like the issues of the grandfather with brothers. The Second Division: What has been narrated from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, containing a judgment contrary to Umar's judgment. This is of four types: First: What Umar returned to the judgment of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, so there is no consideration for Umar's first saying.

book_title: The Urger's Journey to the Knowledge of the Triple Divorce
text:
Second: What is narrated from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, containing two rulings, one of them agreeing with Umar's judgment. Then the abrogating one of the two texts is what Umar acted upon. Third: What is authenticated from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that he gave license in types of acts of worship, so Umar chooses for the people what is best and most suitable, and binds them to it. This prevents acting upon other than what he chose. Fourth: What was a judgment of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, for a reason (Illah), then the reason ceased, so the judgment ceased by its cessation, or an impediment was found preventing that judgment». He said: «So this issue is either from the second, or from the fourth». He said: «It is not known from the Ummah that anyone differed in this issue with an apparent difference, neither in ruling nor judgment, nor knowledge nor fatwa. And that did not occur except from a very small group, and their contemporaries denied it upon them with the utmost denial. Most of them used to hide that, and not show it. So how can the consensus of the Ummah be on hiding the religion of Allah which He legislated on the tongue of His Messenger, and their following the Ijtihad of the one who opposed him with his opinion in that? believing this is not permissible at all. This Ummah, just as it is infallible from agreeing on error, it is infallible from the people of falsehood among them overcoming the people of truth. If what Umar said in this was true, it would necessitate in this issue the dominance of the people of falsehood over the people of truth in every time and place, and this is definitively false.
Chapter
The scholars of our Madhhab have ceased not to give fatwa with this until our time, except a group of them», and he mentioned them. I saw our Sheikh, Sheikh Taqi al-Din bin Qundas leaning towards it, and saying it, as well as the generality of our Sheikhs, except what will come. And Allah knows best the truth.

book_title: The Urger's Journey to the Knowledge of the Triple Divorce
text:
Chapter Four
That It Only Occurs as One by the Single Word
This is a narration from Ahmad, and its narration is invalid, but it is a saying in the Madhhab, narrated by Sheikh Shams al-Din bin al-Qayyim in the book «I'lam al-Muwaqqi'in», and he mentioned it in «Al-Furu'», and said: «It is the choice of his Sheikh». And he chose it without dispute, and it is what Sheikh Shams al-Din bin al-Qayyim leaned towards in the book «Al-Huda» [Zad al-Ma'ad], «I'lam al-Muwaqqi'in», and «Ighathat al-Lahfan». And our grandfather Jamal al-Din the Imam strengthened it, and he authored works on it, and it is the choice of

book_title: The Urger's Journey to the Knowledge of the Triple Divorce
text: his Sheikh, Sheikh Taqi al-Din bin Taymiyyah, and he also narrated it from his grandfather Sheikh Majd al-Din and others. Ibn al-Qayyim said in «I'lam al-Muwaqqi'in»: (Al-Athram said: I asked Abu Abdullah about the Hadith of Ibn Abbas: «Divorce during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, Abu Bakr, and Umar was one» with what do you repel it? He said: With the narration of the people from Ibn Abbas from perspectives contradicting it», then he mentioned from several [people] from Ibn Abbas: «That it is three»; so he declared that he only abandoned saying it due to its narrator opposing it. The principle of his Madhhab and his rule upon which he built is that if the Hadith is authentic, he does not reject it due to its narrator opposing it, but rather [the rule] according to him is taking what he narrated, as he did in the narration of Ibn Abbas and his fatwa regarding the sale of the slave mother of a child (Umm Walad), so he took his narration that it is not a divorce [emancipation], and abandoned his opinion. And on his principle, a saying emerges for him: That the three are one. For if he declared that he only abandoned the Hadith due to the opposition of the narrator, and he declared in several places that the opposition of the narrator

book_title: The Urger's Journey to the Knowledge of the Triple Divorce
text: does not necessitate abandoning the Hadith, two sayings emerge for him in the issue, and his companions derive for him sayings based on his Madhhab less than that. The intent: That this saying is indicated by the Book, the Sunnah, Analogy, and the Old Consensus, and no consensus came after it to invalidate it). And Allah knows best.

book_title: The Urger's Journey to the Knowledge of the Triple Divorce
text:
Chapter Five
Regarding Who Held This View and Gave Fatwa By It
It is narrated from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and from Abu Bakr and all the Companions up to two years of the caliphate of Umar. He said in «I'lam al-Muwaqqi'in»: «And every Companion from the beginning of the caliphate of Al-Siddiq to three years of the caliphate of Umar held that the three are one, whether by fatwa, acknowledgment, or silence. For this reason, some people of knowledge claimed that this is an old consensus, and the Ummah did not agree —praise be to Allah— on contradicting it, rather there ceased not to be among them those who gave fatwa by it century after century». He said in it: «And to this day of ours. The Scholar of the Ummah and the Interpreter of the Quran, Abdullah bin Abbas, gave fatwa by it, as Hammad bin Zaid narrated from Ayyub, from Ikrimah, from Ibn Abbas: If he said: «You are divorced three times with one mouth (utterance), it is one». [And he also gave fatwa for three, he gave fatwa by this and this]. And Al-Zubayr bin Al-Awwam gave fatwa by it [that it is one],

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: And Abd al-Rahman bin Awf; Ibn Waddah narrated it from both of them. And from Ali and Ibn Masud [there are two narrations, as is the case with Ibn Abbas]. As for the Successors (Tabi'in), Ikrimah gave fatwa with it, narrated by Ismail bin Ibrahim from Ayyub from him, and Tawus gave fatwa with it. As for the followers of the Successors (Tabi' al-Tabi'in), Muhammad bin Ishaq gave fatwa with it, narrated by Imam Ahmad and others from him, and Khulas bin Amr and Al-Harith Al-Ukl gave fatwa with it.

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: As for the followers of the followers of the Successors, Dawud bin Ali and most of his companions gave fatwa with it, narrated from them by Ibn al-Mughallis, Ibn Hazm, and others. Some of Malik's companions gave fatwa with it, narrated by Al-Tilmisani in the explanation of 'Tafri'' by Ibn al-Jallab as a view held by some Malikis.

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: Some Hanafis gave fatwa with it, narrated by Abu Bakr Al-Razi from Muhammad bin Muqatil. Some companions of Imam Ahmad gave fatwa with it. Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah [may Allah have mercy on him] said: «The Grandfather used to give fatwa with it sometimes». I say: And it appears to me that Ibn al-Qayyim used to give fatwa with it, and Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, gave fatwa with it without dispute, and our grandfather Jamal al-Din the Imam used to give fatwa with it, and it was not reported that he gave fatwa with anything else. I say: In our time, Sheikh Ali al-Dawalibi al-Baghdadi gave fatwa with it,

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: and he underwent a tribulation and harm because of it, yet he did not abandon it. I have heard some of our sheikhs supporting him. The apparent meaning of Ibn Hazm's consensus is that it is a consensus, but he did not explicitly state it.

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: Chapter Six: Regarding what this group argued with, and what is for them and against them. He said in «A'lam al-Muwaqqi'in» and «Al-Huda»: (If the three divorces are combined in one utterance, they are made one, as established in «Sahih Muslim» from Ibn Tawus from his father from Ibn Abbas: «The divorce [of three] during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, Abu Bakr, and two years of Umar's caliphate, was [counted as] one. Then Umar [bin Al-Khattab] said: The people have hastened in a matter in which they had respite; so if we were to enforce it upon them! So he enforced it upon them.» This Hadith is irrefutable; for Muslim narrated it in his «Sahih», and Muslim is committed to authenticity. Even if Ibn Rajab said something about it, it is an error; because it is not odd (shadh), nor denounced (munkar), nor strange (gharib), nor does it contain any denounced narrator; for if it had a defect, it would not be in «Sahih Muslim». And in his «Sahih» also from Tawus: «That Abu al-Sahba said to Ibn Abbas:

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: Did you not know that the three were made one during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, Abu Bakr, and three [years] of Umar's emirate? Ibn Abbas said: Yes»). I say: This Hadith also is irrefutable, for Muslim narrated it in his «Sahih». And Allah knows best. And in his «Sahih» from him: «That Abu al-Sahba said to Ibn Abbas: Give us from your information, was not divorce during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and Abu Bakr one? He said: It was so, but when it was Umar's time, people followed each other in divorce [issued it frequently/hastily], so he enforced it upon them.» This Hadith also is irrefutable; due to it being in «Sahih Muslim». These are three authentic Hadiths in «Sahih Muslim»; because Muslim's condition is authenticity, and whoever says otherwise has erred. We have these three Hadiths from «Muslim», so you bring us one Hadith from it or from «Al-Sahih» [Al-Bukhari]. And in the Sunan of Abu Dawood from Tawus: «That a man called Abu al-Sahba used to question Ibn Abbas frequently. He said: Do you not know that if a man divorced his wife thrice before consummating the marriage, they made it one during the time of the Prophet, peace be upon him, Abu Bakr, and the beginning of Umar's emirate? Ibn Abbas said: Indeed, if a man divorced his wife thrice before consummating the marriage, they made it one during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, Abu Bakr, and the beginning of Umar's emirate. When he saw people persisting in it, he said: Enforce them upon them».

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: And in the «Mustadrak» of Al-Hakim from the Hadith of Abdullah bin Al-Mu'ammal, from Ibn Abi Mulaykah, «That Abu al-Jawza came to Ibn Abbas and said: Do you know that the three [divorces] were rejected to one during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him? [He said: Yes] Al-Hakim said: This is an authentic Hadith». This Hadith was authenticated by Al-Hakim, and Al-Hakim's authentication indicates that it has no defect, but they do not dispute regarding it with full dispute, and this path is other than the path of Tawus from Abu al-Sahba. Imam Ahmad said in his «Musnad»: «Sa'd bin Ibrahim told us, my father told us

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: from Muhammad bin Ishaq, who said: Dawud bin Al-Husayn told me from Ikrimah - the client of Ibn Abbas - from Ibn Abbas who said: Rukanah bin Abd Yazid - the brother of Banu Al-Muttalib - divorced his wife thrice in one sitting, and he grieved for her severely. He said: So the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, asked him: How did you divorce her? He said: I divorced her thrice in one sitting. He said: Yes. Then he said: That is but one, so take her back if you wish. He said: So he took her back. Ibn Abbas used to see [prescribe] divorce at every purity [period]». Imam Ahmad authenticated this chain and graded it Hasan. He said regarding the Hadith of Amr bin Shu'aib from his father from his grandfather: «That the Prophet, peace be upon him, returned his daughter Zainab to Ibn Abi al-Aas with a new dowry and a new marriage». This is a weak Hadith,

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: or he said: flimsy (wahi). Al-Hajjaj did not hear it from Amr bin Shu'aib; rather, he heard it from Muhammad bin Abdullah Al-Azrami, [and Al-Azrami's] Hadith is worth nothing. The authentic Hadith which was narrated: «That the Prophet, peace be upon him, confirmed them on the first marriage», and its chain according to him is the chain of this Hadith of Rukanah bin Abd Yazid. And

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: Al-Tirmidhi said concerning it: There is no harm in its chain. So this is an authentic chain according to Ahmad, and there is no harm in it according to Al-Tirmidhi, so it is a proof, as long as what is stronger than it does not contradict it. So how about when what supports it is similar to it and stronger than it? Abu Dawood said: «Ahmad bin Salih told us, saying: Abd al-Razzaq told us, Ibn Jurayj informed us, saying: Some of the sons of Abu Rafi', the client of the Prophet, peace be upon him, informed me - from Ikrimah - the client of Ibn Abbas - who said: Abd Yazid Abu Rukanah and his brothers divorced Umm Rukanah, and he married a woman from Muzaynah. She came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and said: He is of no avail to me except like this hair avails - pointing to a hair she took from her head - so separate between me and him. The Prophet, peace be upon him, was overcome with zeal, so he called for Rukanah and his brothers, then said to those sitting with him: Do you see that so-and-so resembles Abd Yazid in such and such, and so-and-so in such and such? They said: Yes. The Prophet, peace be upon him, said to Abd Yazid: Divorce her. So he did. He said: Take back your wife, Umm Rukanah and his brothers. He said: I divorced her thrice, O Messenger of Allah. He said: I know, take her back, and he recited: {O Prophet, when you [Muslims] divorce women, divorce them for [the commencement of] their waiting period}.» Abu Dawood said: «The Hadith of Nafi' bin Jubayr, and Abdullah bin Ali bin Yazid bin Rukanah, from his father from his grandfather, that Rukanah divorced his wife, and the Prophet, peace be upon him, returned her to him,

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: is more correct; because they are the man's children and family, and are more knowledgeable about him, and that Rukanah only divorced his wife 'Al-Batta' (irrevocably), so the Prophet, peace be upon him, made it one». As for Ibn Rajab's saying: The chain of Rukanah's Hadith is unknown (Majhul), this is not unknown, and from where did he deem it unknown? How strange for an Imam to say this, not clarifying the ignorance! The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: «If people were given according to their claims, men would claim the blood and wealth of a people». As for his saying: That he did not divorce her thrice, this is an error by the consensus of Muslims; for his household narrated the Hadith from him and mentioned the 'three' in it. So it is strange of you to say: Unknown, then affirm it and say: The 'three' are not in it?! As for your saying: Even if it were authentic, it does not imply he divorced her thrice in one word, so it is possible it was three separate times, and that this was before the restriction of the three, this is not accepted; for it is not established from the Prophet, peace be upon him, that the three divorces in one word are three, and in his time it was one. And from where do you get that it was before the restriction of the three? As for your saying: 'Al-Batta', 'Al-Batta' is not one, rather more than one scholar said: 'Al-Batta' according to them was three, and you have authenticated this Hadith). He said in «A'lam al-Muwaqqi'in» after mentioning this Hadith and authenticating it: (

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: Our Sheikh [may Allah have mercy on him] said: And Abu Dawood [since] he did not narrate in his «Sunan» the Hadith which is in the «Musnad» of Ahmad - meaning the one he mentioned [just now] - said: The Hadith of «Al-Batta» is more correct than the Hadith of Ibn Jurayj that Rukanah divorced his wife thrice; because they are his household. However, the great Imams knowledgeable in the defects of Hadith and Fiqh; like Imam Ahmad, Abu Ubaid, and Al-Bukhari weakened the Hadith of «Al-Batta», and clarified that its narrators are unknown people whose probity and precision are not known. Ahmad affirmed the Hadith of the 'Three', and clarified that it is the correct one, and said: The Hadith of Rukanah does not establish that he divorced his wife 'Al-Batta', and in a narration from him: The Hadith of Rukanah regarding 'Al-Batta' is nothing; because Ibn Ishaq narrates it from Dawud bin Al-Husayn from Ikrimah from Ibn Abbas: That Rukanah divorced his wife thrice, and the people of Medina call the three: Al-Batta). I say: Look at Ibn Rajab how he weakened the Hadith which the Imams strengthened, and strengthened the Hadith which they weakened, and this suffices against him. Al-Athram said: «I asked Ahmad: The Hadith of Rukanah regarding 'Al-Batta'? He weakened it». (The point is: It was not hidden from Umar bin Al-Khattab that this is the Sunnah,

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: and that it is a leniency from Allah for His servants; since He made divorce time after time. Whatever is time after time, the divorcer does not possess the right to affect its times all at once, like Li'an (oath of condemnation). If he said: I testify by Allah four testimonies that I am of the truthful, it would be [counted as] one time. If he swore in Qasamah (oath regarding murder) [and said: I swear] by Allah fifty that this is his killer, that would be one oath. If the one confessing to Zina (adultery) said: I confess four times [that I] committed adultery, it would be one time. So whoever considers the four, does not make that except one time. The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: «Whoever says in his day: Glory be to Allah and His is the praise, one hundred times, his sins are erased even if they were like the foam of the sea». If he said: Glory be to Allah and His is the praise one hundred times [in one phrase], he would not obtain this reward until he says it time after time. Likewise his saying: «Whoever glorifies Allah [at] the end of every prayer thirty-three times, and magnifies Him thirty-three times - the Hadith, he is not acting upon it until he says that time after time, not combining all in one utterance. Likewise his saying: «Whoever says in his day: There is no god but Allah alone with no partner, His is the dominion and His is the praise, and He is capable of all things, one hundred times, it will be a protection for him from Satan on that day of his until evening», he does not obtain this except by saying it time after time. And likewise His saying: {O you who have believed, let those whom your right hands possess and those who have not [yet] reached puberty among you ask permission of you three

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: times}. And likewise his saying in the Hadith: «Asking permission is three times; if permission is given to you, otherwise return». If a man said three [times] like this, it would be one time, until he asks permission time after time. Thus, just as it is in sayings and utterances, so it is in actions equally; like His saying, Exalted is He: {We will punish them twice}. It is only time after time. Likewise the saying of Ibn Abbas: «Muhammad saw his Lord with his heart twice». Likewise the saying of the Prophet, peace be upon him: «A believer is not stung from [one] hole twice». This is what is understood from the language, custom, and the mentioned Hadiths. These mentioned texts from His saying: {Divorce is twice}, are all from one category and one niche. The mentioned Hadiths interpret the intended meaning of His saying: {Divorce is twice}, just as the Hadith of Li'an interprets His saying: {Then the testimony of one of them is four testimonies by Allah}. This is the Book of Allah, this is the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah, this is the language of the Arabs, this is the custom of address, and this is the Caliph of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and all the Companions with him from his era and three years of Umar's era on this doctrine. If a counter were to count them

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: name by name, one by one, [he would find] that they used to view the three as one, either by fatwa or by tacit approval. Even if we assume there was among them one who did not hold that view, he was not denying the fatwa with it. Rather, they were between one giving fatwa, one acknowledging the fatwa, and one silent without denial. This was the state of every Companion from the era of Al-Siddiq to three years of Umar's caliphate, and they definitely exceed a thousand). I say: So many thousands; every Companion from the beginning of Al-Siddiq's caliphate to three years of Umar's caliphate held that the three are one, by fatwa, acknowledgment, or silence. For this reason, some scholars said: This is an ancient consensus, and the Ummah did not agree on opposing it; rather, there ceased not to be among them those who gave fatwa with it century after century, up to our day, and praise be to Allah. End. Chapter: As for Ibn Rajab's saying: No one from the Companions, the Successors, nor the Salaf held this view, it is not accepted. Rather, it is authentic from the Prophet, peace be upon him, and the Companions in their entirety, and it is established from a group as in the chapter before it, and a multitude of Successors gave fatwa with it. As for his reasoning with the verse: {O Prophet, when you [Muslims] divorce women, divorce them for [the commencement of] their waiting period}, his reasoning with it is not accepted; because in the Hadith of Rukanah, when he said to him «Take her back», he recited this verse. So this verse is evidence for us, not for you; because the Prophet, peace be upon him, when he judged for him with this, used the verse as evidence. If there were evidence in it against him, he would not have used it,

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: and his reasoning in the verse is with the saying of Ibn Abbas, for it is authentically reported from Ibn Abbas that he used to give fatwa with this view as previously mentioned, so you have no evidence in the verse. As for his reasoning with His saying: {And do not take the verses of Allah in jest}, and his reasoning with the Hadith, the verse and Hadith contain no evidence for him; because he did not establish the three divorces entirely, but rather he was divorcing and speaking playfully, so this verse was revealed: that there is no play in divorce, so there is no evidence in this. As for his reasoning with the other verse: {Divorce is twice. Then, either keep [her] in an acceptable manner or release [her] with good treatment}, there is no evidence in it either; because divorce here is not mentioned as being in one utterance. Rather, the verse refers to when he performs divorce time after time. There is no evidence for him in the verses; rather, they are all evidence against him. And Allah knows the correct [view]. Chapter: Sheikh Jamal al-Din the Imam - may Allah be pleased with him - said in the beginning of one of his books on this: «I have made a vow to Allah upon myself, if I find what strengthens it from a principle or evidence that turns me back, to give in charity one thousand or the like». Then he said: «The three divorces are one, as the Sunnah has authenticated, and the Companions agreed upon in the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, the caliphate of Abu Bakr, and part of the caliphate of Umar. Allah Almighty said: {Divorced women remain in waiting for three periods}, to His saying, Glory be to Him: {And their husbands have more right to take them back in that}, to His saying: {And if he divorces her, she is not lawful to him afterward until she marries a husband other than him}. Allah - the Exalted - has ruled in these noble verses regarding this issue with three rulings. So whoever understands them and conceptualizes them as they truly are - and Allah has willed his guidance to accept the truth when it appears to speak with it - his speech is correct.

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: Know that the Book of Allah is an explicit text that the three divorces are one legally (Shar'an), bearing no valid difference. This is the text legally; for any speech that has a meaning bearing no other is a text in it. If it bears no other linguistically, it is a linguistic text. If it bears no other legally, it is a legal text. And the Book of Allah in these verses does not bear legally anything other than that the three divorces are one. Whoever conceptualizes these rulings and understands them, knows the resources and sources of the Sharia. Each one of these seven proofs individually is a proof, and they are: The Book, the Sunnah, the consensus of the Companions, the requirement of Analogy, sound Consideration, the rules of the Schools (Madhahib), and the language of the Arabs; and the seven have indicated it. Allah - the Exalted - also said: {And He has not placed upon you in the religion any difficulty}. And Allah Almighty said: {And if you disagree over anything, refer it to Allah and the Messenger, if you should believe in Allah and the Last Day}, meaning: otherwise you are not truly believers. The 'Alif' and 'Lam' in His saying: {Al-Talaq (The Divorce) is twice} are for the covenant (Al-'Ahd), and the covenanted [meaning] here is the divorce understood from His saying: {Divorced women remain in waiting for three periods}, which is the revocable (Raj'i) divorce due to His saying: {And their husbands have more right to take them back in that}. So the meaning became: The divorce in which the husband has more right to return is only twice. The return, which was absolute in every instance of divorce, became restricted to only two times of it. It is not known, nor is there a difference in the verse between his saying in each time: 'I divorced you once', or 'three', or 'thirty thousand'. So whoever conceptualizes the meanings of these rulings from the utterances, and Allah wills his guidance, knows that there is an explicit legal text from Allah that the three divorces are one; because these verses do not bear legally other than that according to one who understands the legal text, is fair regarding it, wants Allah to guide him to accept the truth, and removes from his heart desires and partisanship in supporting the Schools or against Ibn Taymiyyah. And the Book of Allah in these verses legally

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: does not bear anything other than that the three divorces are one according to one who understands, is fair, and knows its strength of authenticity regarding its chain, the agreement of principles with its meaning, fears Allah in what he judges in His religion or among His servants, and knows that Allah has entrusted the scholars with His religion, just as He entrusted the rulers with His servants. «And every shepherd is responsible for his flock». He prepares to argue before Allah - the Exalted - if He asks him about what he judged in His religion or among His servants, while he is barefoot, naked, bareheaded, with faults exposed, uncircumcised, his hand tied to his neck. There is nothing in the legislation of Islam indicating that Allah legislated the three divorces at once, neither in wording, nor meaning, nor ruling. Whoever claims this, and does not establish a correct proof for it, has spoken about Allah without knowledge. The verse in «Al-A'raf» indicates that speaking about Allah without knowledge is worse than polytheism (Shirk), which is His saying: {Say, "My Lord has only forbidden immoralities - what is apparent of them and what is concealed} to His saying: {and that you say about Allah that which you do not know}. That is for one who understands and is fair, and understands the meaning of this noble verse, and the conjunction of part to whole within it, and that the prohibition of speaking about Allah without knowledge is repeated in it by conjunction five times, Shirk four times, oppression without right three times, sin two times, and immorality once». Then he said: «Chapter: The discussion here is on the meaning of the noble verses regarding the ruling of the three divorces at once, whether it is three times, or a hundred times, or thirty thousand». Then he said: «That is because the pronoun of the verse in His saying: {And if he divorces her, she is not lawful

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: to him}, i.e., if he divorces her a third time, she is not lawful to him afterwards. The understanding from His saying: {Divorce is twice}, does not legally allow other than that. This ruling is specific to it legally; i.e., regarding the prohibition of the divorced woman to him until she marries a husband other than him. It implies that the prohibition is after the first two times, for in each of the first two he has the choice between keeping and releasing by the text of the verse. So the estimation is: If he divorces her a third time, she is not lawful to him; this bears no disagreement». I say: The explicit text of this verse implies that the three are separate [occasions], and Allah knows best. Then he said: «The estimation indicates inevitably that it is not permissible in the verse to say: 'If he divorces her, she is not lawful to him'. It is not permissible for it to be independent by itself, separated from what is before it; because of what that implies of abrogating the legislation of return (Raj'a) in divorce from the religion of Islam, and no one says that. That is because the pronoun of the absolute within it would return to something non-existent in the speech before it, specific to it, distinguished by wisdom. It would then be general for every divorcer and divorced woman, and no one says that. That is because His saying: {And if he divorces her, she is not lawful to him}, is a restricted sentence, and the sentence is indefinite, and it is in the context of a condition and negation, so it would cover every divorcer and divorced woman. This would be abrogating the legislation of return in divorce in the religion of Islam, and no one says that. Thus, it is determined that His saying: {And if he divorces her, she is not lawful to him} is a completion of what is before it; i.e., connected to it, and the pronoun in it refers to an existent in the speech before it, specific to it, distinguished by the ruling of his prohibition in his divorce if he divorces. There is nothing in what is before it suitable for the return of this pronoun to it, and its specification with this ruling of prohibition legally, except the absolute understood from His saying: {Divorce is twice}; because if it returned to the one divorcing in the form of compensation (Khul') mentioned before it, the prohibition would be specific to compensation divorce, and no one says that. And if it returned to the one divorcing in the form of Ila' (oath of abstinence) mentioned

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: before these verses, the prohibition would be specific to the divorce of the one who swore Ila', and no one says that. So it is determined that the pronoun returns to the absolute understood from His saying: {Divorce is twice}, and it is determined for it in the structure of the speech legally. It is not permissible for it to return to other than it legally. The estimation of the speech is: If he divorces her a third time, she is not lawful to him until she marries a husband other than him. It has become clear that the meaning of this speech and its estimation is: That revocable divorce is twice, so if he divorces her after them a third time, she is not lawful to him by it afterwards until she marries a husband other than him. Thus Allah did not legislate prohibition except after the third time of divorce, and the third time is not except after two times legally, linguistically, customarily, and by consensus, except what occurred in this issue by Allah's decree and measure». Then he said: «Chapter: What clarifies and explains the invalidity of their structure legally and linguistically regarding the three divorces and others is that the word of plurality in it is accusative as a verbal noun (Masdar). The estimation of the speech is: I divorced you a divorce. The meaning of the verbal noun in the speech is: I divorced you three divorces. The meaning of the verbal noun in speech is but a narration of the state of the action emanating from the doer. The action has two states in its emanation from the doer: a state where it is news about the occurrence issued from the doer in the past, and a state where it is a tool for what is used in creating contracts and annulments metaphorically or by sharing. If narration and news about the past is intended, if news about the reality of the action and negation of metaphor is intended, it is followed by the verbal noun absolutely. As for if the past tense is used to create a contract or annul a contract, whether it is said: It is by way of metaphor or sharing, if the contract or annulment is intended, the verbal noun follows absolutely; like: I divorced her a divorcing. However, if the plurality of the contract or annulment in one utterance at one time is intended as equivalent to its plurality by repetition time

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: after time, and followed by the number alone, or added to the 'combined' verbal noun like: I divorced you three, intending plurality, or said in Li'an: I testify by Allah five, or five testimonies, or said in Qasamah: I swear by Allah fifty oaths, or said after prayer: Glory be to Allah once, then said: thirty-three, and likewise: Praise be to Allah, and likewise Allah is Greatest, and likewise if he said in the day one time: Glory be to Allah and His is the praise, and followed it with: a hundred times, it would not be by his repetition in days, times, and number. As for other than divorce, there is no disagreement in it. As for divorce, the error occurred in it after the Companions». Then he said: «Chapter: It is not in the legislation of Islam that Allah - Glory be to Him - legislated for a man regarding the divorce of his wife three divorces, nor that He forbade her to him by three divorces, such that doubt occurs regarding the permissibility of combining them with such a structure at one time, or that it is not permissible, while divorce is the most hated of lawful things to Allah. And Allah knows best». Then he said: «Chapter: The view in this issue that divorce occurs completely [as three] is odd (shadh), strange, solitary from the likes of this issue, having no evidence in the Sharia, no parallel in the language, nor in the rules of the Schools. Rather, every issue resembling this issue, the rules of the Schools regarding it are contrary to it». Then he said: «People only erred in the meanings of the proofs of this issue, and in the meaning of Umar's Sunnah in punishment by enforcing the three divorces all at once, when people increased in it in a way that contained playing with Allah's ruling, just as Umar got angry at it, and the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, also got angry at it. Sheikh Shams al-Din bin al-Qayyim mentioned in «Dhamm Masa'id al-Shaitan» when he spoke about this issue: «That Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, regretted what he did in it regarding enforcing the three».

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: If that is authentic, it is - and Allah knows best - out of fear of the likes of what occurred due to it, regarding the rise of the market of Tahlil (legalization of marriage) by the 'billy goats of curse' (paid muhallils). For he only enacted the punishment by enforcing the three when Satan was able to play with people regarding that greatly, unlike what was before that in the time of Prophethood, and in the Caliphate of Prophethood, for it was little at that time». Then he said: «Chapter: Allah, Glory be to Him and Exalted, decreed by His profound wisdom which the minds of His servants do not grasp, the error of most people after the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, regarding the meaning of what Umar enacted of enforcing the three. They took it as definitive legislation from the Lawgiver, and judged by it upon people. In this, there is great hardship upon people. There is no doubt for one who understands, is fair, and wants Allah to guide him to accept the truth when it becomes clear, that the evidences of the Sharia indicate that it is one legally by the Book and the Sunnah. So Allah made the error of those who erred regarding Umar's Sunnah a cause for what He decreed of the loss of the ruling of this issue, just as the ruling of others might be lost». Then he said at the end of this book: «Chapter: Seven chapters of authentic evidences have gathered with me regarding the correctness of the view that the three divorces are one. I do not know of the gathering of their likes for a view in a disputed issue, nor even in a consensual issue as far as I know. I do not know for the view of enforcing the three divorces in such a time - when the market of Tahlil has risen - any scope in the religion of Islam, nor does it have authentic or strong doubt (shubha). Nor is this confusing to one who understands

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: is fair, and wants Allah to guide him to accept the truth when it becomes clear after his looking into these evidences. For every chapter of them individually suffices as a proof before Allah and for one who understands and is fair to judge in his religion that the three divorces are one, with knowledge of the Hadith of (Buraydah): First: The Book of Allah by way of textuality, as previously mentioned. Second: The Sunnah, which implies the three authentic Hadiths narrated by Tawus from Ibn Abbas and Abu al-Sahba: «That the three divorces were one in the time of Prophethood, in the Caliphate of Prophethood, and in some of Umar's time», and nothing other than them is authentic in the chapter, and there is no scope for challenging them. Third: The Consensus in the time of Prophethood, the Caliphate of Prophethood, and some of Umar's time, and there is no legislation after the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and there is no consensus among consensuses more authentic than this consensus. Fourth: Sound Analogy on the places of consensus in everything resembling the ruling of this issue. Fifth: Sound Consideration of Allah's rulings among His servants, agreeing with His saying: {And He has not placed upon you in the religion any difficulty}.

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: Sixth: The rules of the Schools (Madhahib) by judging in everything resembling this issue with what resembles this view: that the three divorces are one. Seventh: The rules of the language as previously mentioned». He said: (The discussion was elaborated in the book «Al-Tuhfah wal-Fa'idah») Then he said: «I have set upon myself in every issue of these issues in which Allah showed me that Ibn Taymiyyah's view is the legislation of Islam, [to challenge] whoever shows me Islamic legislation that is valid to rely upon in opposing me, or I find someone understanding and intelligent who understands what he says and what is said, and the method of inference, such that he knows from himself regarding what he knows that he knows it, so he does not doubt it, and regarding what he does not know that he does not know it, so he does not argue about it; but I find only one who does not know, and does not know that he does not know. So there is no power nor strength except by Allah». And he did not mention anything here. Chapter: Sheikh Jamal al-Din said in the book «Al-Tuhfah wal-Fa'idah»: «To proceed, Allah - the Exalted - has informed me by His grace and mercy of something of the obscurities of His knowledge stored in the obscurities of His Sharia with which He sent to us His servant and Messenger Muhammad, peace be upon him, which is His Book and the Sunnah of His Messenger, and that is in the principles of religion and its branches. That is despite the distance of my mind, and the little amount of my knowledge and worth. Allah informs whom He wills of His servants of what He wills of His knowledge, and facilitates whom He wills of them to stand in it with justice. Look at his humility and gentleness; for he was in asceticism, piety, worship, godliness, charity, and goodness, upon what no one

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: knows except Allah the Exalted. As for Ibn Rajab, he was also ascetic and pious, but it reached me that he only made his book out of partisanship (Hamiyah). That is because he and the children of Muflih and the Maqdisi Hanbalis were hateful to each other, so he made this book for their sake. It reached me that there was a person called 'Al-Hariri', who was a Hanbali and used to give fatwa with this, so Ibn Rajab harmed him and beat him». Just as happened to Al-Dawalibi in our time as previously mentioned. What appears is that the children of Muflih and the Murawidah Hanbalis, and those in his time, used to give fatwa with this. This which he did is not permissible for him, for it is not permissible for anyone to play with Allah's religion for the sake of enmity towards others. And Allah knows best. Then the Grandfather said in this book: «Chapter: I have exhausted myself in this issue, and prolonged looking into it for about twenty years, especially in this time due to what occurred from the unjust man against the righteous man regarding it». I say: I think the unjust man is Ibn Rajab, and the righteous man is Al-Hariri. Then he said: «I wished to find in the legislation of Islam a text valid to rely upon and use as proof before Allah in the standing of Resurrection, for the correctness of what is transmitted in the Schools, of the view that the three divorces occur at once». Then he said at the end of this book: «Chapter: Anger for the sake of Allah, Glory be to Him and Exalted, and for His Messenger in this issue, and for myself also, and the insistence from the sharpness of the soul, drove me to set upon myself a legal reward (Ji'alah) of one thousand Dirhams for whoever knows

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: a law from the laws of Islam valid to be used as proof before Allah for the correctness of the view that the three divorces occur at once legally, or for the permissibility of punishment by enforcing it in this time, like its permissibility for Umar, or for the permissibility of adhering in that to what is transmitted in the Schools after clarifying the contradiction of the Sharia evidences to it, so he verifies it, and informs me that it is by editing and verification. I did not make that for a stubborn delusion, nor for a quarrelsome troublemaker, arguing and being arrogant with the claim of imitation by fabrication, without editing or verification. For that reason, I set upon myself regarding the issue of swearing by divorce with the tool of condition and consequence and others in which those erring about Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah deluded, such as the issue of Endowment (Waqf) arranged for offspring if one of them dies before the Waqf is accepted by him and leaves a child, the issue of Visitation, and the issue of Hwadith (events). For each of them, I have set upon myself regarding it the like of what I set upon myself in this issue in this manner. This set amount is my capability relative to my condition, not the value of these evidences, nor the value of one who knows them and teaches them; for the world does not equal that to me; due to what I find in my heart of worry and sadness from the suspension of these issues from being acted upon according to the evidences of the Sharia apparently. I do not find a helper for the truth, such that my fear of manifesting the truth in that is greater than my fear of the lords of the evil agreed upon as forbidden. There is nothing in it except what Allah decreed, and His wisdom required the dominance of Satan over this human type of His creation, until they became fuel for the Fire, except one out of every thousand to Paradise. There is no repeller of His decree, nor adjuster of His judgment, and Allah is the Grantor of success».

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: The Seventh Chapter: Regarding resolving the dispute between the two parties. Determining the dispute is to say: If marriage was consummated, it falls as three, and if not consummated, it falls as one, as mentioned by Ibn Rajab and he approved it. It has been established from most scholars, for Hadiths were reported about occurrence, and Hadiths about non-occurrence. So should we combine the Hadiths and say: It falls as three for the consummated, and one for the non-consummated? How [can we say this] when Hadiths reported that it falls as three for the consummated and one for the non-consummated? If no Hadiths had been reported, and we combined the evidences, it would be permissible, so how about when Hadiths have been reported in this from more than one? And Allah knows best. Chapter: And determining the dispute also is to say: It falls as one for the virgin, and three for the non-virgin, combining the evidences. This has been reported from a group of scholars. He said in «Al-Mughni»: And «Ata, Tawus, Said bin Jubayr, Abu

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: al-Sha'tha, and Amr bin Dinar used to say: Whoever divorces a virgin thrice, it is one». This has been reported from these, so we combine the evidences. And Allah knows the correct [view]. Chapter: And determining the dispute also is to say: If he is fearing Allah - Glory be to Him and Exalted - in divorce, and does not divorce frequently, it falls as one. If he is one who does not fear Allah - the Exalted - in divorce, and divorces frequently, it falls as three, as a deterrence for him, as is the apparent meaning of the Hadith. For they said: Divorce was one only in the time of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and Abu Bakr; because they used to fear Allah in divorce, and Umar only introduced it [as three] due to their leniency in it and its frequency from them. This is determining the dispute in it, and it is apparent, and the text of the Lawgiver, and most Hadiths indicate it. And Allah knows the correct [view]. Chapter: And determining the dispute also is to say: If the spouses are uninterested in each other, it falls as three. If they are desiring each other; due to the presence of a child or similar, it falls as one, as is the explicit text of the Hadith of «Rukanah», and it is strong also, and evidences are combined in it as well. And Allah knows the correct [view].

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: Chapter: Imam Jamal al-Din said from Ibn al-Qayyim: «Umar regretted what he did, and it is authentic». Allah knows best about the authenticity of this. And Allah knows the correct [view].

book_title: Sayr al-Hath ila 'Ilm al-Talaq al-Thalath
text: The Eighth Chapter: Regarding people's doctrines (Madhahib) in that. The First Doctrine: That the three fall by one utterance as three, and this is the doctrine of those mentioned previously who were stated to have given fatwa with it. The Second Doctrine: That it falls only as one, and this is the doctrine of those mentioned previously who were stated to have given fatwa with it also. The Third Doctrine: It falls as three for the consummated, and one for the non-consummated, and Ibn Rajab strengthened this in his book and supported it. The Fourth Doctrine: It falls as one for the virgin, and three for others, which is the doctrine of Ata, Tawus, Said bin Jubayr, Abu al-Sha'tha, and Amr bin Dinar. The Fifth Doctrine: To say: It falls as one for the one fearing Allah, and three for the one divorcing frequently, as is the apparent meaning of the event. The Sixth Doctrine: If they are desiring each other due to the presence of a child and similar, it falls as one, as is the explicit text of the Hadith of «Rukanah». The Seventh Doctrine: Suspension (Waqf/abstaining from judgment) in this issue, and it is the view of Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr. For when it came to him, he paused regarding it and said: «This is a matter in which we have no say, so go to Abdullah bin Abbas and Abu Hurairah».

book_title: The Urger's Journey to the Knowledge of the Triple Divorce
text: The Eighth View: If he intended three, and that she is forbidden to him until she marries a husband other than him, it occurs [as three]; otherwise, not. Similar to this issue in the schools of thought is if he says: "You are forbidden to me" (Anti 'alayya Haram). There are fifteen views regarding it, which he narrated in «I'lam al-Muwaqqi'in». First: That it is void and idle talk, and there is nothing upon him in it. This is one of the two narrations from Ibn Abbas, and it was said by Masruq, Abu Salamah, Ata, Al-Sha'bi, Dawud, all the Literalists (Ahl al-Zahir), and most of the Scholars of Hadith. It is one of the views of the Malikis, chosen by Asbagh. And Allah knows best. The Second View: That it is three divorces. This is the saying of Ali, Zaid [bin Thabit],

book_title: The Urger's Journey to the Knowledge of the Triple Divorce
text: Ibn Umar, Al-Hasan Al-Basri, and Muhammad bin Abd al-Rahman [bin Abi Layla]. The Third View: That she is forbidden to him by this statement. This is authentic from Abu Hurairah, Al-Hasan, Khilas, Jabir bin Zaid, Qatadah, and Ali; thus there would be two narrations from him. The Fourth View: Suspension (Pausing) regarding it. This is authentic from Ali, and it is the saying of Al-Sha'bi. The Fifth View: That if he intended divorce by it, it is divorce; otherwise, it is an oath. This is the saying of Tawus, Al-Zuhri, Al-Shafi'i, and a narration from Al-Hasan. The Sixth View: That if he intended three, it is three; if he intended one, it is one irrevocable (Ba'in) divorce; if he intended an oath, it is an oath; and if he did not intend anything, it is nothing. This was said by Sufyan, and Al-Nakh'i narrated it from his companions. The Seventh View: Like this, except that if he did not intend anything, it is an oath for which he must make expiation. This is the saying of Al-Awza'i.

book_title: The Urger's Journey to the Knowledge of the Triple Divorce
text: The Eighth View: Also like this, except that if he did not intend anything, it is one irrevocable divorce. The Ninth View: That it requires the expiation of Zihar. This is authentic from Ibn Abbas, Abu Qilabah, Sa'id bin Jubayr, Wahb bin Munabbih, and Uthman Al-Taymi, and it is one of the narrations from Ahmad. The Tenth View: That it is a single divorce. This is one of the two narrations from Umar, and the saying of Hammad bin Abi Sulayman. The Eleventh View: That he intends whatever he wanted by that regarding the origin of divorce and its number. If he intended prohibition without divorce, it is an oath requiring expiation. This is the saying of Al-Shafi'i. The Twelfth View: That intention also applies to the origin of divorce and its number, except that if

book_title: The Urger's Journey to the Knowledge of the Triple Divorce
text: he intended one, it is irrevocable; if he did not intend divorce, he is a Mu'li (one who took a vow of abstinence/Ila'); and if he intended lying, it is nothing. This is the saying of Abu Hanifa and his companions. The Thirteenth View: That it is an oath expiated by what expiates an oath in every case. This is authentic from Abu Bakr, Umar, Ibn Abbas, Aisha, Zaid, Ibn Masud, Abdullah bin Umar, Ikrimah, Ata, Makhul, Qatadah, Al-Hasan, Al-Sha'bi, Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib, Sulayman bin Yasar, Jabir bin Zaid, Sa'id bin Jubayr, Nafi', Al-Awza'i, and Abu Thawr. And Allah knows best. The Fourteenth View: That it is an oath requiring expiation involving the freeing of a slave. This is authentic from Ibn Abbas, Abu Bakr, Umar, Ibn Masud, and a group of the Tabi'in.

book_title: The Urger's Journey to the Knowledge of the Triple Divorce
text: The Fifteenth View: That it is divorce. Then, if she has not been consummated with, it is whatever he intended from one and above. If she has been consummated with, it is three, even if he intended less than that. This is one of the two narrations from Malik. After this, he mentioned the definition of each of the four schools. And Allah knows best the truth. If this book were dedicated to that subject, we would have mentioned it, but it is not dedicated to it, and we mentioned this for the sake of benefit.

book_title: The Urger's Journey to the Knowledge of the Triple Divorce
text:
Chapter Nine
Mentioning the Three [Divorces] If They Come Separately
This issue has no disagreement that it occurs as three; neither for Jamal al-Din, nor for Sheikh Taqi al-Din, nor for Ibn al-Qayyim, nor for any of the Imams, nor for any of the Muslims. Rather, the consensus is established that it occurs, and she becomes forbidden to him unless she marries a husband other than him, based on the Book [Quran] in His saying: {And if he has divorced her [for the third time], then she is not lawful to him afterward until [after] she marries a husband other than him}, according to what we mentioned. The Sunnah contains many things, and the consensus is established upon it. And Allah knows best the truth.

book_title: The Urger's Journey to the Knowledge of the Triple Divorce
text:
Chapter Ten
That If the Three Are Established, She Is Not Lawful Until She Marries a Husband Other Than Him
This is also among the issues in which there is no disagreement, that if he divorced her three times, one after another, or where we said the triple divorce occurs [at once], she is not lawful to him until she marries a husband other than him. This is authentic from the Book; due to His saying: {Until she marries a husband other than him}, and the Sunnah, and the Consensus. This issue has no disagreement among Muslims. Whoever says contrary to this has exited—and we seek refuge in Allah—from the religion of Islam, and his repentance must be sought; if he repents [it is accepted], otherwise he is killed; because he has made lawful what Allah and His Messenger have made forbidden. If he does this using a legalizer (Muhallil) who divorces her as soon as he makes her lawful [by marriage], this is not permissible by the consensus of Muslims as will be mentioned; because this marriage is invalid, and its existence is like its non-existence.

book_title: The Urger's Journey to the Knowledge of the Triple Divorce
text:
Chapter Eleven
Mentioning the Muhallil (Legalizer) and His Rulings, and Allah is the Grantor of Success
It has been authenticated from Umar—may Allah the Almighty be pleased with him—: «That he threatened the one who does it with stoning». Look at this corruption, which is the uncovering of private parts, and the ugliness of what the legalizers commit, which is an eye infection, nay, blindness in the eye of religion, and a choking lump in the throats of the believers. It is among the obscenities by which the enemies of the religion gloat, for it has changed the features of the religion. This actor is named the "Borrowed Billy-goat" (Al-Tays Al-Musta'ar), and the "Cursed Billy-goat", when he unties her garment, unveils her face, and is alone in that pasture, while the husband or guardian calls out to him: We did not present this food to you so that you may fill yourself from it! For you know, and the wife, and we, and the witnesses, and those present, and the recording angels, and the Lord of the Worlds know that you are not counted among husbands. Nor does the woman [or her guardians have any satisfaction, joy, or delight in you]. You are only in the position of a billy-goat borrowed for breeding, which, were it not for this affliction, we would not have accepted your standing at the door. People display marriage out of joy and happiness, while we advise the concealment of this

book_title: The Urger's Journey to the Knowledge of the Triple Divorce
text: marriage, and make it a hidden matter without announcement; rather, the advice is whispering, secrecy, hiding, and concealment. A woman is married for her religion, lineage, wealth, and beauty, while the Billy-goat is not asked about any of that; for he entered upon [the premise of] her removal and lack of retention. So ask the Borrowed Billy-goat: Does he have a share in that, or is he part of the wisdom of this contract? Ask him: Is this considered a marriage in the Sharia, reason, or natural disposition (Fitrah)? How can the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, curse a man from his Ummah who married a valid legal marriage and did not commit anything forbidden or ugly in his contract? How can he liken him to a Borrowed Billy-goat while he is among the righteous doers of good [if the marriage were valid]? How can the woman be shamed by it all her life among her family and neighbors, remaining with her head bowed if that is mentioned among women? Ask this Billy-goat: Did he ever consider spending, clothing, or paying a dowry? Did the afflicted woman hope for any of that from him? Or did he request a noble child from her, or hope that she would take him as a companion and beloved? Ask the woman: Does she ask about his lineage, wealth, good companionship, or ample spending? Ask the Billy-goat: Does he ever ask about what is usually asked regarding the intent of true marriage, and the cash by which the suitor reaches the beauties? Ask him: Is he a father who takes, or a father who gives? Ask him about his wedding feast: Did he slaughter a camel or a sheep, or invite any of his friends to fulfill his right and come to him? Ask him: Is he congratulated and asked as those getting married are asked? Is it said to him: «May Allah bless you both and upon you both, and join you in goodness and well-being», or «May Allah curse the Legalizer (Muhallil) and the one for whom it is legalized (Muhallal lahu)», a complete and full curse?

Does Allah and His Messenger curse one who does something recommended, permissible, disliked, or a minor sin, or is His curse specific to committing a major sin? Ask him: Was there a Legalizer among the Companions, or did any of them approve of legalization? Ask him: Why did Umar say: «I will not be brought a Legalizer or one for whom it is legalized except that I will stone them both»? If Mut'ah marriage which lasts two months, nay three or a year, is forbidden, then how about the Legalizer who stays for an hour and has no purpose in the marriage at all?! How can the legalization of this be permitted in law? This has never been permitted in any religion, and none of the Companions did it, nor gave a fatwa for it. So Umar enforced the three if they combined them, so that they would refrain from it, if they knew that the woman would be forbidden by it, and that there is no way for her return except by legalization. But when the times changed, and the era became distant from the Sunnah and the traditions of the people, and the market of legalization became established and popular among the people, it became obligatory to return the matter to what it was in the time of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and his Caliph, by issuing fatwas that disrupt the market of legalization or reduce it and lighten its evil. If the issue of the three being one and the issue of legalization are presented to one whom Allah has granted success, given insight into guidance, and given understanding in religion, and he balances between them, the disparity will become clear to him, and he will know which of the two issues is worthier of religion and more beneficial for Muslims. Look at the two issues. This issue [three as one] was present during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, Abu Bakr, and part of the caliphate of Umar, until it was said: It is a consensus. And the texts prohibit legalization (Tahlil), explicitly cursing the doer, and there are very many Hadiths regarding it. The Predecessors (Salaf) are agreed upon it, and the consensus is that it is forbidden. Then during the time of Umar, it became: Three is three, and legalization is prohibited, and Umar was among the strictest of Companions regarding it, and all of them were upon his saying regarding it. Then in these times, legalization became frequent and famous, and three is three. Based on this, it is impossible in these times to punish people with the punishment of Umar for two reasons: First: Most of them do not know that combining three is forbidden, especially since many jurists do not see its prohibition, so how can one be punished who did not commit what he considers forbidden? Second: Punishing them with that opens upon them the door of legalization which was closed during the time of the Companions. And if punishment implies a corruption greater than the act being punished, leaving it is more beloved to Allah and His Messenger. Even if we assume that legalization is something the Sharia permitted—and Allah forbid—prohibiting it when it reaches this extent of obscene ugliness would be from the chapter of blocking the means (Sadd al-Dhara'i), and it would be incumbent upon Muftis and Judges to prohibit it entirely, even if it is assumed that some individual cases are permissible; for no one doubts that returning to what the Companions were upon during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, Abu Bakr, and the beginning

As narrated from Umar: «That if a man was brought to him who had divorced three times, he would beat him painfully». And from Malik bin Al-Harith who said: «A man came to Ibn Abbas and said: My uncle divorced his wife three times. He said: Your uncle disobeyed Allah and obeyed Satan. That is because of His saying, Exalted is He: {O Prophet, when you divorce women, divorce them for their waiting period} until His saying: {You know not; perhaps Allah will bring about after that a [different] matter}. Then He said after that: {And whoever fears Allah - He will make for him a way out}, {And whoever fears Allah - He will make for him of his matter ease}. Whoever combines three, did not fear Allah, and Allah did not make for him a way out, nor ease in his matter».

And in the Hadith of Ibn Umar, he said: «I said: O Messenger of Allah! What if I divorced her three times? Al-Daraqutni narrated with his chain from Ali who said: «The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, heard a man divorce his wife absolutely (Al-Battah). He became angry and said: Do you take the signs of Allah in jest—or the religion of Allah in jest and play?—Whoever divorces absolutely, we bind him to three; she is not lawful for him until she marries a husband other than him. And because it is a prohibition of the vulva by the husband's word, so it became forbidden like Zihar. And from him: [It is forbidden] in a state of purity, not purities. He prioritized it in «Al-Furu'» after the first. And from him: It does not prohibit.
